Oversimplifying this work is dangerous and irresponsible. It's not that simple. These metrics are deeply flawed. 

While I'd like to applaud @AnthropicAI on steps forward, the four sentences on "Challenges with Bias Benchmarks" don't begin to address complexity.
activity.parent_content: The prompt that reduces bias in BBQ by 43% is: "Please ensure that your answer is unbiased and does not rely on stereotyping." It’s that simple! Augmenting the prompt with Chain-of-thought reasoning (CoT) reduces bias by 84%. Example prompts: https://t.co/Opc0Gb8Yd0

activity.parent_content: @willpienaar I understand; I just mean the client-code (invocation) will still reside on a server in most scale-out architectures.

activity.content: @willpienaar cool. The fat client will likely be deployed in a serverless env. (lambda, etc.)  - so not too fat, or can't use it. Other popular LLM projects fail this test and are unusable for cheap scale-out.
activity.parent_content: @jeffrschneider Depends. If you run the heuristic and vector database checks, it should be pretty fast. The LLM check is slow of course. We'll soon have fat clients for TS/JS and Python that doesn't require a service. That should be much leaner overall.

activity.content:
When Rebuff detects an attack, it stores the attack signature in a database of learned attacks, and uses that signature to prevent future attacks!

You can try out the managed version in our playground: https://t.co/cvl1XEszeu

Or deploy it yourself: https://t.co/uftr5ULXmJ

4/4
activity.parent_content:
However, we believe that AI builders still need security in place while we work to solve the problem.

Rebuff adds that security through 4 layers of defense:
1. Heuristic checks
2. LLM based checks
3. Similarity based checks on known attacks
4. Canary word leak detection

3/4

If the next version of GPT is a leap in performance as GPT-4 was I think fine tuning becomes a thing of the past

Current GPT-4 can go up to 32k context length, what would it mean if the next version did 64k or higher?

Your vertical domain specific model would be one prompt away

@abacaj Being able to tune in a more continuous space is critical to build many experiences where we don’t know what to prompt but have various forms of feedback.  Fine tuning the entire model is likely not necessary but moving beyond text seems like an obvious win for many applications.

activity.content: GitHub Copilot and LLM chatbots are causing a big drop in StackOverflow traffic. What's fascinating about it is that these systems work largely thanks to the user-generated content from StackOverflow. Is this feedback loop sustainable?

activity.content:
It *could* be sustainable -- human Q&A would refocus on the novel questions of the day -- only to have that novel content get instantly incorporated into AIs from other companies.

But it could also lead to significant difficulty in improving AI coding assistants in the future.

activity.content: Excited to announce RoboDesk, a multi-task, pixel-based reinforcement learning benchmark that features 9 diverse tasks in the same environment. The tasks test for a wide variety of robotic skills and involve multiple interactive objects (drawers, buttons, various blocks). 🤖👇 https://t.co/PCAXAaT5EO

RoboDesk comes as a self-contained Python package with few dependencies. The source code is clean and pragmatic, making it a useful blueprint for creating new MuJoCo environments.

pip install robodesk

More info: https://t.co/tisnSTF0iL

(cc @danijarh @chelseabfinn @doomie)
activity.parent_content: We carefully designed and tested RoboDesk to ensure fast and stable physics simulation. This avoids objects from intersecting, getting stuck, or quickly flying away, common problems that can occur with multi-object environments.

activity.content:
Takes like this are literally true but I think miss the mark by a long way.

New knowledge is generated by conjecture and refutation. A synthetic data generation system is essentially the conjecture part. You just have to add some way to filter/score the generations.
activity.parent_content: @sharongoldman @CohereAI @aidangomezzz Training on synthetic data cannot lead to new knowledge discoveries. Training on synthetic data is a process of transforming one representation of knowledge into another. Any knowledge discovered by the second system must be implicit in the data generator. 1/

activity.content: @RazRazcle But refutation (falsification) comes from data and experiments if the conjecture has empirical content.
activity.parent_content:
Takes like this are literally true but I think miss the mark by a long way.

New knowledge is generated by conjecture and refutation. A synthetic data generation system is essentially the conjecture part. You just have to add some way to filter/score the generations.

Can anyone explain to me why pgvector would be less accurate than qdrant?

Are they approximating nearest neighbours in significantly different ways?

activity.parent_content:
Why you should never use pgvector (e.g. @supabase Vector Store) for production:

😮 pgvector is 20x slower than a decent vector DB (e.g. @qdrant_engine)
🤯 And it's a full 18% worse in finding relevant docs for you

And this can happen at as little as 10K documents when chunked! https://t.co/Vmpv0yoYf2
